The online submission portal opens on February 16, 2026, with a final submission deadline of April 10, 2026 (11:59 PM CET). This annual funding opportunity supports projects that drive meaningful change in communities where Alstom operates. NGOs partnering with an Alstom employee as Project Promoter are invited to submit proposals aligned with the Foundation s strategic priorities. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(119); }); Key Dates for the 2026 Cycle February 10 March 13, 2026: Project definition and preparation with partners March 13, 2026: Deadline to request assistance in identifying an Alstom Promoter February 16, 2026: Online submission portal opens April 10, 2026 (11:59 PM CET): Final deadline for project submission Mid-September 2026: Board selection of funded projects Implementation: Ongoing monitoring throughout the year Focus Areas of the Alstom Foundation The Alstom Foundation concentrates on four key axes of intervention: ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); 1. Economic and Social Development Projects under this axis should promote sustainable livelihoods and inclusive growth. Priority is given to: Skills development and employability programs for disadvantaged youth and women Support initiatives for street children, orphans, and foster children ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); 2. Environmental Protection The Foundation funds projects that enhance environmental awareness, safeguard biodiversity, protect natural habitats, and strengthen community resilience to natural disasters. 3. Access to Mobility Proposals should facilitate safe and inclusive movement of people and goods, especially in remote or underserved communities, enabling better access to markets, healthcare, and education. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); 4. Access to Energy and Water Projects that improve access to electricity and safe drinking water are strongly encouraged. With millions globally lacking these essential services, the Foundation aims to raise living standards in vulnerable communities through sustainable solutions. Selection Criteria To be considered for funding, each project must: Align with at least one of the Foundation s key focus areas Serve the general interest Be located in a country where Alstom has a presence Demonstrate measurable outcomes and community impact Be realistic and feasible within budget and timeline Involve local stakeholders and local management Be implemented by a competent partner organization Comply with the Foundation s Ethics Charter Be submitted in the same country where the Alstom employee promoter is based Each NGO may submit only one project per cycle. The Role of the Alstom Promoter Every submission must be jointly prepared by an NGO and an Alstom employee serving as Project Promoter. The promoter must be based in the same country where the project will be implemented. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); The promoter collaborates in preparing and validating the project file and, if selected, assists in monitoring implementation. If an NGO does not know an Alstom employee, it may request support from the Foundation Secretariat to identify a potential promoter. However, requests must be submitted no later than March 13, 2026. The Secretariat does not guarantee that a promoter will be identified, as promoters participate on a voluntary basis. How to Submit The online submission tool opens on February 16, 2026. Applicants complete structured, preformatted forms designed to optimize proposal clarity. A help function is available within each form. Drafts can be saved and edited before final submission. Once submitted, the selection process begins automatically. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(131); }); Applicants will receive a confirmation email upon successful submission. Interested NGOs should begin early preparation to ensure compliance with all guidelines and partnership requirements before the April 10, 2026 deadline. title: Youth, Peace and Security Online Course 2026: UN-Certified Training to Implement the YPS Agenda
summary: Build Practical Skills to Advance Youth Participation in Peace and Security Young people are increasingly recognized as powerful agents of change in preventing conflict, sustaining peace, and shaping inclusive security policies. To translate global commitments into real-world impact, practitioners need the right skills, frameworks, and tools. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(119); }); Realizing the Youth, Peace and Security Agenda is a comprehensive, practitioner-focused online course jointly developed by United Nations System Staff College and the Folke Bernadotte Academy . The programme equips professionals working in peace and security with the knowledge and applied competencies needed to effectively implement the Youth, Peace and Security (YPS) agenda while working with and for young people. Why This Course Matters The adoption of landmark UN Security Council resolutions 2250 (2015), 2419 (2018), and 2535 (2020) elevated youth participation in peace and security from aspiration to international obligation. Despite progress, implementation remains uneven across local, national, and global levels. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); This course responds directly to that gap by offering a structured, skills-based learning journey that strengthens institutional capacity and supports young women and men as contributors to peaceful and just societies.
